items.title: AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'sleep'
items.body:
Hello, I would like to ask why I would have this error,

my python version:
Python 3.7.7 (default, May  6 2020, 11:45:54) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
Type "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

IPython 7.16.1 -- An enhanced Interactive Python.

My code (all the code after the error have been commented):
import time
import pyautogui
print ('Start')
pyautogui.FAILSAFE=True
pyautogui.time=1
print('1')
time.sleep(2)
mousePos = pyautogui.position()
print('2')
pyautogui.click(mousePos, interval=0)
# print('3')
# while True:
#     print('4.1')
#     pyautogui.press(['/'])
#     print('4.2')
#     pyautogui.typewrite('Hello World, THIS IS A AUTOMATIC PYTHON LOOP!\n', interval=0.25)
#     print("DONE!!")

I hope you can help in this issue
full error message:

runfile('C:/Macro/temp.py', wdir='C:/Macro')
Start
1
2
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "C:\Macro\temp.py", line 10, in <module>
    pyautogui.click(mousePos, interval=0)

  File "C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs\AI\lib\site-packages\pyautogui\__init__.py", line 588, in wrapper
    returnVal = wrappedFunction(*args, **kwargs)

  File "C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs\AI\lib\site-packages\pyautogui\__init__.py", line 985, in click
    time.sleep(interval)

AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'sleep'

items.title: version: 0.9.45 let h scroll bar move failure, dragRel/hscroll
items.body:
my version is : 0.9.45
when i was use blew code, the drag effect not display:

    pyautogui.hscroll
    pyautogui.dragRel

so, i use the another way that pywinauto to deal with my problem:

    import pywinauto.mouse
    pywinauto.mouse.press(coords=(371, 736))
    pywinauto.mouse.move(coords=(1371, 736))
    pywinauto.mouse.release()

thank you

items.title: click funtion wont working on anydesk application
items.body:
Hi, I want to write a Script that click on accept button of any desk connection.
Mouse will move to that x, y but can't click. I think it is some security thing. 

Do you have idea how can I bypass this?

items.title: can't take screenshot more than 1000 times at a go
items.body:
I had to automate screenshot which does happen but i can't take more than 1000 screenshots using "for loop".

I have defined a function where i press few keyboard buttons then take screenshot, after  that i "for loop" it for 1000 shots. 

  don't get the image files but it does press the same button, any way to change this functionality ?

Any place in the source where i can change the limits of no. of screenshots ??

Thanks a lot, in advance !!

items.title: "Module not found error"
items.body:
After installing with the following command `pip3 install pyautogui`, I have found the following error when trying to import it:
```bash
homelyseven250@my-pc:~/Documents/Python Tests$ python3 test1.py 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test1.py", line 1, in <module>
    import pyautogui 
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pyautogui'
```
Is this an error with Python or my Ubuntu 18.04 machine or with pyautogui?
Any help would be appreciated.

items.title: incorrect shift-key sequences in __init__.py
items.body:
### Pre:
On a Belgian AZERTY keyboard, keys like `! $ & < : ; ( )` are non-shift keys. 

### Problem:
```
In [1]: import pyautogui

In [2]: pyautogui.write('"')

In [3]: 3
```

3 would be the result with a shift key pressed.

### Expected:
```
...
in[3]: "
```

### Cause:

`__init__.py`'s `isShiftCharacter()` checks if the characters are in a hardcoded string: 

```
return character.isupper() or character in '~!@#$%^&*()_+{}|:"<>?'
```

### Solution:
Starting from the original keys (I haven't checked keys that aren't in the string), this would be a better set of Shift-enabled keys for Belgian AZERTY: `~@#%^*_+{}|>?`

Allthough it would be cleaner if we could somehow test the current keyboard layout and set the string of shift-characters that way.

items.title: Please use the following code for image matching
items.body:
# def find_image(needle, haystack):
    im = np.atleast_3d(haystack)
    tpl = np.atleast_3d(needle)
    H, W, D = im.shape[:3]
    h, w = tpl.shape[:2]

    # Integral image and template sum per channel
    sat = im.cumsum(1).cumsum(0)
    tplsum = np.array([tpl[:, :, i].sum() for i in range(D)])

    # Calculate lookup table for all the possible windows
    iA, iB, iC, iD = sat[:-h, :-w], sat[:-h, w:], sat[h:, :-w], sat[h:, w:]
    lookup = iD - iB - iC + iA
    # Possible matches
    possible_match = np.where(np.logical_and.reduce([lookup[..., i] == tplsum[i] for i in range(D)]))

    # Find exact match
    for y, x in zip(*possible_match):
        if np.all(im[y + 1:y + h + 1, x + 1:x + w + 1] == tpl):
            return (y + 1, x + 1)

    raise Exception("Image not found")


This piece of code will increase the speed of image matching by 2x-10x

I am trying to use `pyautogui` to click on a text input or text document and then input text.

I am entering the following into a shell (`(370, 80)` are the coordinates of my Chrome address bar):

`pyautogui.click(370,80); pyautogui.typewrite('Hello world!')`

`click()` seems to not be working as expected. It will highlight text in an input when I click on the input, but even when I manually type after the click, the text shows up in the shell. See [this screenshot](https://imgur.com/3EF0dBA) of the result of running the above line.

Other methods like `position()`, `moveTo()`, `moveRel()`, and `dragTo()` are working as expected. Pausing before `typewrite()` (as in `pyautogui.click(370,80); time.sleep(3); pyautogui.typewrite('Hello world!')`) doesn't fix it.

If I run `time.sleep(5); pyautogui.typewrite('test')` and manually click on the text document or input while the thread is sleeping, the text is inputted as desired.

What might be the problem? I've had the same issue on both Macs I've tested on.

items.title: [enhancement] Add Recording Feature
items.body:
Hey Al, amazing program and course! (Automate the Boring Stuff w/Python)

I was thinking, it'd be really cool a record feature in PyAutoGUI.

What I mean with a record feature is the ability to let's say, call a method (just like `displayMousePosition()`) add a delay of X seconds to start recording the movements of the cursor and then start recording those coordinates.

So that will allow users to record what they want to do in a more faster way, instead of checking the coordinates of various points they want to click/drag and then annotate them, they can record the actions they want to do in the program and replicate the behavior. In order to stop the recording, there should be kill-switch like a key combination on the keyboard, just like screen recorders do.

After the recording, PyAutoGUI can save the replicated movements/actions in a file specified by the user at the end of the recording, and use that program to replicate that behavior again.

What do you think? 🙂

items.title: Suggesstion: Rewrite the LocateOnScreen function with python-opencv
items.body:
The  function `LocateOnScreen` not works perfectly sometimes so I  rewrite this function with python-opencv lib  in my private project.

Docs about `Template Matching`: http://opencv-python-tutroals.readthedocs.io/en/latest/py_tutorials/py_imgproc/py_template_matching/py_template_matching.html#template-matching-with-multiple-objects

code:

```
def locate_on_screen(tpl_path):
    screenshot_img = 'locate_on_screen_image_{}.png'.format(time.time())
    gui.screenshot('/tmp/{}'.format(screenshot_img))

    img_rgb = cv2.imread('/tmp/{}'.format(screenshot_img))
    img_gray = cv2.cvtColor(img_rgb, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
    template = cv2.imread(tpl_path, 0)
    w, h = template.shape[::-1]
    res = cv2.matchTemplate(img_gray,template,cv2.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED)
    threshold = 0.8
    loc = np.where( res >= threshold)

    # debug
    for pt in zip(*loc[::-1]):
        return (pt[0], pt[1],  w , h)

    return False
```

items.title: Fuzzy matching
items.body:
locateOnScreen() and the other functions do a pixel-perfect match (unless opencv is installed).

These functions are slow (they can take a full second to run), but if we only checked half of the pixels then we could speed up the runtime by not checking every pixel. This could (but probably won't in 99% of cases) lead to false positives.

items.title: Making pyAutoGUI work on a remote machine....
items.body:
Hi,
I have found that it's possible to make some aspects of pyAutoGUI work on a remote machine (e.g. moveTo and click) and my question is whether this could be made to work for other functions (e.g. alert).

If my Python is running on 192.168.1.1 and I want to control the mouse and keyboard on 192.168.1.2, this works;
```
import pyautogui
import Xlib
from time import sleep

class g:
    xDisplay = "192.168.1.2:0.0"

# This is the magic bit
pyautogui.platformModule._display = Xlib.display.Display (g.xDisplay)

# Lets print out the size of the remote screen
screenWidth, screenHeight = pyautogui.size()
print screenWidth, screenHeight

# Put a message box on the screen
# pyautogui.alert ("Hi David")      # Goes to local display

# Take a screen shot
#pyautogui.screenshot ("dgw.png")   # Gets local display

# Go into a location on the remote screen
pyautogui.moveTo (770, 200)
sleep (1)
pyautogui.click ()
sleep (1)

```
I have to enter something like this first on .2
Old Debian machine
```
    export DISPLAY=":0.0"
    xhost +
```
I have managed to make it work on a newer Ubuntu machine by adding this to lighdm config;
Create a text file here;
` /usr/share/lightdm/lightdm.conf.d/100-remoteX.conf
`
Then enter the following;
```
[SeatDefaults]
xserver-allow-tcp=true
```
Getting back to the question, I wonder if there's any way to make more of the functions work on the remote machine?

Thanks for your attention.

Dave

items.title: Sending "Ctrl-C" hotkey combination does not work
items.body:
I've been searching for a solution to this for several days, but am beginning to wonder if I'm just looking at a bug.

I have a script that needs to copy to the clipboard using Ctrl + C, but somehow sending this key combination has lost functionality in pyautogui.

There is no exception thrown, and it appears everything is executing as it should be. However, the desired text is not copied to the clipboard. Copying the text manually using Ctrl + C (on my actual keyboard) does cause the desired text to be copied. However, when running pyautogui the clipboard remains unchanged.

I found this question on Stack Overflow that verifies the issue:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38899566/python-pyautogui-and-ctrl-c?newreg=4a6bdd511c314b129438d6d79f427600

I am also running Windows 7 and Python 3.5, as is Todd Lewden, the author of the Stack Overflow question.

The "Cheat Sheet" on Read the Docs indicates that this functionality should be present in pyautogui:

> Keyboard hotkeys like Ctrl-S or Ctrl-Shift-1 can be done by passing a list of key names to hotkey():
> 
> > > > pyautogui.hotkey('ctrl', 'c')  # ctrl-c to copy
> > > > pyautogui.hotkey('ctrl', 'v')  # ctrl-v to paste

I'm not sure at what point sending the "Ctrl + C" combination became broken, but it looks like it worked at some point, according to the above reference to the documentation. 

I had a thought that perhaps it has to do with "Ctrl + C" being a Python keyboard interrupt, but I don't know that that is the case. If it were, Python should come to a screeching halt when the Ctrl + C is sent. It appears to execute without error, except that it doesn't work.

items.title: Add German support for typewrite()
items.body:
From a user's email:

I use PyAutoGUI-0.9.33-py3.4.egg-info in one of my programs. When I use the function pyautogui.typewrite special characters like ö,ä,ü,#,@ ß, do not work.

I found an workaround for me on the following side:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13289777/how-can-i-send-keyboard-commands-hold-release-simultanous-with-a-python-script

Maybe you can use this code for windows, so special characters are also supported if it not already work now.

Thank you for your time and thanks for PyAutoGUI :)

Following the code that works for me:

import ctypes
import time

SendInput = ctypes.windll.user32.SendInput

PUL = ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_ulong)
class KeyBdInput(ctypes.Structure):
    _fields_ = [("wVk", ctypes.c_ushort),
                ("wScan", ctypes.c_ushort),
                ("dwFlags", ctypes.c_ulong),
                ("time", ctypes.c_ulong),
                ("dwExtraInfo", PUL)]

class HardwareInput(ctypes.Structure):
    _fields_ = [("uMsg", ctypes.c_ulong),
                ("wParamL", ctypes.c_short),
                ("wParamH", ctypes.c_ushort)]

class MouseInput(ctypes.Structure):
    _fields_ = [("dx", ctypes.c_long),
                ("dy", ctypes.c_long),
                ("mouseData", ctypes.c_ulong),
                ("dwFlags", ctypes.c_ulong),
                ("time",ctypes.c_ulong),
                ("dwExtraInfo", PUL)]

class Input_I(ctypes.Union):
    _fields_ = [("ki", KeyBdInput),
                 ("mi", MouseInput),
                 ("hi", HardwareInput)]

class Input(ctypes.Structure):
    _fields_ = [("type", ctypes.c_ulong),
                ("ii", Input_I)]

def writetext(text_unicode):
        def PressKey_local(KeyUnicode):
            extra = ctypes.c_ulong(0)
            ii_ = Input_I()
            ii_.ki = KeyBdInput( 0, KeyUnicode, KEYEVENTF_UNICODE, 0, ctypes.pointer(extra) )
            x = Input( ctypes.c_ulong(1), ii_ )
            ctypes.windll.user32.SendInput(1, ctypes.pointer(x), ctypes.sizeof(x))
        def ReleaseKey_local(KeyUnicode):
            extra = ctypes.c_ulong(0)
            ii_ = Input_I()
            ii_.ki = KeyBdInput( 0, KeyUnicode, KEYEVENTF_UNICODE|KEYEVENTF_KEYUP, 0, ctypes.pointer(extra) )
            x = Input( ctypes.c_ulong(1), ii_ )
            ctypes.windll.user32.SendInput(1, ctypes.pointer(x), ctypes.sizeof(x))  
        for c in text_unicode:
            PressKey_local(ord(c))
            ReleaseKey_local(ord(c))

writetext("Ölgemälde")

items.title: Non-linear X/Y movement of the mouse (enhancement)
items.body:
In the real world, the mouse does not move linear.
Fix it: rewrite getPointOnLine to getPointOnCurve.
Open black screen and run.

```
import pyautogui
import pytweening

def getPointOnCurve(x1, y1, x2, y2, n, tween=None, offset=0):
    """Returns the (x, y) tuple of the point that has progressed a proportion
    n along the curve defined by the two x, y coordinates.
    If the movement length for X is great than Y, then Y offset else X
    """
    # for compatibility Backward
    if getPointOnCurve.tween and getPointOnCurve.offset:  # need DEL
        tween = getPointOnCurve.tween                     # need DEL
        offset = getPointOnCurve.offset                   # need DEL

    x = ((x2 - x1) * n) + x1
    y = ((y2 - y1) * n) + y1
    if tween and offset:
        offset = (n - tween(n)) * offset
        if abs(x2 - x1) > abs(y2 - y1):
            y += offset
        else:
            x += offset
    return (x, y)

#----------------------------------

getPointOnCurve.tween = None
getPointOnCurve.offset = 0

def set_curve(func, tween=None, offset=0):
   func.tween = tween
   func.offset = offset

#----------------------------------

print 'Linear >'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(800, 500, 2)

pyautogui.getPointOnLine = getPointOnCurve  #   Replacement

print 'Curve easeInCubic'
set_curve(getPointOnCurve, pytweening.easeInCubic, 100)
print '>'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(800, 500, 2)
print 'v'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 800, 2)
print '<'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(200, 500, 2)
print '^'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 200, 2)

print 'Curve easeOutCubic'
set_curve(getPointOnCurve, pytweening.easeOutCubic, 100)
print '>'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(800, 500, 2)
print 'v'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 800, 2)
print '<'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(200, 500, 2)
print '^'
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 200, 2)

print 'Curve easeInOutCubic > 50'
set_curve(getPointOnCurve, pytweening.easeInOutCubic, 50)
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(800, 500, 2)

print 'Curve easeInOutCubic > 100'
set_curve(getPointOnCurve, pytweening.easeInOutCubic, 100)
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(800, 500, 2)

print 'Curve easeInOutCubic > 100'
set_curve(getPointOnCurve, pytweening.easeInOutCubic, 200)
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(800, 500, 2)

print 'Curve easeInOutCubic \ 100'
set_curve(getPointOnCurve, pytweening.easeInOutCubic, 100)
pyautogui.moveTo(500, 500)
pyautogui.moveTo(800, 800, 2)
```

items.title: Doesn't work with Cyrilic.
items.body: `pyautogui.typewrite('раз два три')` creates a couple of spaces but doesn't write any Cyrillic letters.

items.title: installation via pip fails on headless machines
items.body: Please don't call Xlib.Display constructor at module-level scope in _pyautogui_x11.py.
